statement.text: Completion angiography is an intraoperative imaging technique performed at the end of a vascular reconstruction to identify technical errors before wound closure. This quality control measure involves injecting contrast through the bypass graft or arterial reconstruction and obtaining fluoroscopic images to assess anastomotic patency, identify stenoses, confirm runoff adequacy, and detect intimal flaps or thrombus. Studies demonstrate that completion imaging detects actionable findings in 5-15% of cases.
statement.formal: Completion Angiography: Puncture graft/artery proximal to reconstruction → Inject iodinated contrast → Fluoroscopic imaging of anastomoses and runoff → Assess: patency, stenosis, intimal flap, thrombus, runoff | Detection rate: 5-15% actionable findings | Impact: Reduces early graft failure

explanation.intuition: Completion angiography is like doing a final inspection before you close up the hood of a car after a repair. You're checking your work to make sure everything is connected properly, there are no leaks or blockages, and the blood (like fuel in a car) can flow where it needs to go. Finding a problem now is much easier than finding it after the patient leaves the OR.
explanation.key_insight: The value of completion imaging is in preventing early graft failure. Technical errors (intimal flaps, anastomotic stenosis, retained thrombus) cause 50-70% of early bypass failures. Fixing these problems intraoperatively takes minutes; coming back for a failed graft takes hours and has worse outcomes. The radiation and contrast exposure is minimal compared to the benefit.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Complete all anastomoses and restore flow; (2) Prepare C-arm fluoroscopy with digital subtraction capability; (3) Choose access site: directly puncture graft, insert needle through graft hood, or place catheter antegrade; (4) Use 18-gauge needle or micropuncture system; (5) Connect to contrast injector or syringe; (6) Position C-arm for optimal view (AP, obliques as needed); (7) Inject contrast (10-20cc iodinated contrast for hand injection, more for power injection); (8) Acquire digital subtraction images during injection; (9) Image entire reconstruction from inflow to runoff; (10) Assess: inflow, proximal anastomosis, graft body, distal anastomosis, runoff vessels. Interpretation: Look for filling defects (thrombus, intimal flap), stenosis (>30% narrowing concerning), kinks, and adequacy of runoff.
common_misconceptions: If the pulse feels good, you don't need imaging - palpable pulse doesn't rule out significant stenosis
Completion imaging is only for complex cases - all bypasses benefit, tibial bypasses especially
Finding a problem means the operation failed - finding and fixing it is a success
The radiation isn't worth it - doses are low and benefit is high

definitions_glossary.digital_subtraction_angiography: Fluoroscopic technique subtracting background to highlight contrast-filled vessels
definitions_glossary.intimal_flap: Dissection of arterial intima that can cause stenosis or thrombosis
definitions_glossary.runoff: Outflow vessels beyond the reconstruction that receive blood from the bypass
definitions_glossary.filling_defect: Area within contrast column that doesn't fill, suggesting thrombus or flap

indications: After lower extremity bypass (especially tibial bypass)
After any vascular reconstruction where technical error is possible
Suboptimal Doppler signal or pulse after reconstruction
contraindications: Severe contrast allergy (relative - consider CO2 angiography)
Severe renal insufficiency (relative - minimize contrast volume)

access_options.direct_graft_puncture: Puncture prosthetic graft directly (not for vein grafts)
access_options.hood_puncture: Puncture through anastomotic hood before completion
access_options.catheter_placement: Leave catheter in graft from antegrade approach

imaging_views: Lateral for profunda origin if included
Runoff views to foot if tibial bypass

interpretation_criteria.normal: Smooth contrast flow, no filling defects, no stenosis
interpretation_criteria.filling_defect: Intimal flap or thrombus - requires correction

complications.prevention: Pre-treatment for known allergy, use CO2 if severe
Use small needle, direct pressure after

outcomes.revision_rate: 3-8% of cases revised based on findings

definition.@value: Intraoperative fluoroscopic imaging performed after vascular reconstruction to identify technical errors before wound closure

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Intraoperative Assessment.
Mills JL, et al. Completion arteriography and intraoperative duplex scanning. J Vasc Surg.

learning_objectives: Describe the technique of completion angiography
Interpret completion angiograms for technical errors
Understand the impact on bypass patency outcomes
Select appropriate imaging modality for quality control
clinical_pearls: A 5-10% revision rate based on completion imaging is normal and expected
If you find nothing abnormal on completion imaging, you're probably not looking hard enough
Tibial bypasses have the most to gain - small technical errors cause failure
CO2 is a good alternative for patients with contrast allergy or renal failure
Don't skimp on views - obliques show stenosis hidden on AP images

medicalCode.description: Angiography, extremity, unilateral, radiological supervision and interpretation
